name: Milky Way
structure: Central bulge, spiral arms, and halo
formation: Formed from smaller protogalaxies through mergers
funFact: Contains our Solar System!

name: Andromeda
structure: Two major spiral arms with star-forming regions
formation: Result of galaxy mergers
funFact: On a collision course with the Milky Way!

name: Messier 87 (M87)
blackHole: First imaged by Event Horizon Telescope
structure: Massive elliptical structure with hot gas
formation: Formed through repeated mergers of smaller galaxies
funFact: Its black hole’s shadow was the first ever photographed!

name: Whirlpool Galaxy (M51)
blackHole: Likely has a central black hole
structure: Grand-design spiral with well-defined arms
formation: Formed from interactions with companion galaxy NGC 5195
funFact: Famous for its interacting companion galaxy

name: Sombrero Galaxy (M104)
structure: Distinct central bulge with dust lane
formation: Likely evolved from smaller structures
funFact: Looks like a sombrero hat in optical images

name: Messier 81 (Bode’s Galaxy)
structure: Well-defined spiral arms with central bulge
formation: Formed from early accretion of gas and dust
funFact: One of the brightest galaxies visible from Earth

name: Messier 82 (Cigar Galaxy)
structure: Irregular shape with intense star formation
formation: Formed through interactions with nearby galaxies
funFact: Produces superwinds from massive star formation

name: NGC 3370
structure: Loose spiral arms with young star-forming regions
formation: Formed from gradual gas accumulation
funFact: Home to observed Type Ia supernovae used to measure cosmic distances

name: NGC 4945
structure: Dusty spiral with active nucleus
formation: Result of galactic interactions
funFact: Brightest infrared galaxy in the southern sky

name: NGC 2903
structure: Barred spiral with active star-forming regions
formation: Formed from accretion and interactions
funFact: Rich in star formation and young stellar clusters

name: NGC 4565 (Needle Galaxy)
structure: Edge-on spiral with thin disk
formation: Formed from gas accretion over billions of years
funFact: One of the best examples of an edge-on spiral galaxy

name: NGC 7331
structure: Spiral arms with central bulge and disk
formation: Gradual buildup through mergers and accretion
funFact: Often called the ‘Milky Way’s twin’

name: IC 342 (Hidden Galaxy)
structure: Face-on spiral with dusty star-forming regions
formation: Formed in dense star-forming regions
funFact: Difficult to observe due to foreground stars and dust

name: NGC 1300
structure: Barred spiral with tightly wound arms
formation: Formed from accretion and interaction
funFact: Showcases a large, symmetrical bar at the center

name: NGC 628 (M74)
structure: Grand-design spiral with visible arms
formation: Built from slow accumulation of gas and stars
funFact: Often used in studies of spiral structure and star formation

name: NGC 253 (Sculptor Galaxy)
structure: Spiral with starburst activity
formation: Formed from gas accretion and interactions
funFact: One of the brightest starburst galaxies

name: NGC 1097
structure: Barred spiral with central ring structure
formation: Formed through interactions and mergers
funFact: Has a striking circumnuclear ring of star formation

name: NGC 4038 (Antennae Galaxies)
structure: Two colliding spiral galaxies
formation: Currently merging through gravitational interaction
funFact: Famous for starburst regions triggered by collision

name: NGC 3621
structure: Grand-design spiral with clear arms
formation: Built through gradual accretion and star formation
funFact: Has well-defined spiral arms and active star formation

name: NGC 6744
structure: Large spiral resembling the Milky Way
formation: Formed through star formation and mergers
funFact: One of the largest known spiral galaxies

name: NGC 5033
structure: Spiral with loosely wound arms
formation: Formed through gradual accretion of gas
funFact: Features a warped disk and active star formation

name: NGC 2905
structure: Spiral galaxy with moderate star formation
formation: Built from interactions and gradual star formation
funFact: Less studied but offers insights into star formation

name: NGC 3310
structure: Irregular spiral with bursts of star formation
formation: Likely formed from a recent merger event
funFact: Known for intense regions of new stars forming

name: NGC 3627 (M66)
structure: Grand-design spiral with strong arms
formation: Formed through interactions with nearby galaxies
funFact: Part of the Leo Triplet, interacting with nearby galaxies

name: NGC 4559
structure: Spiral galaxy with active star-forming regions
formation: Formed from slow accumulation of matter
funFact: Contains multiple young star clusters and nebulae

name: NGC 1365
structure: Barred spiral with central ring and well-defined arms
formation: Formed through accretion and interactions
funFact: Known as the ‘Great Barred Spiral Galaxy’

name: NGC 2403
structure: Grand-design spiral with active star formation
formation: Formed gradually through gas accumulation
funFact: Contains numerous H II regions and star clusters

name: NGC 3079
structure: Edge-on spiral with central bulge and starburst nucleus
formation: Formed through interactions and star formation
funFact: Shows superwind activity from central starburst region

name: NGC 7332
structure: Smooth disk with little spiral structure
formation: Formed through gas depletion and aging stellar population
funFact: Often studied as a typical lenticular galaxy

name: NGC 7742
structure: Face-on spiral with bright ring and central bulge
formation: Formed through secular evolution and minor interactions
funFact: Also called the ‘Fried Egg Galaxy’ due to its appearance

name: NGC 2903
structure: Barred spiral with prominent star formation
formation: Built through gas accretion and stellar evolution
funFact: Contains multiple H II regions and young star clusters

name: NGC 1360
structure: Smooth elliptical shape with little gas
formation: Formed through mergers and star aging
funFact: Typical elliptical galaxy with older stellar population

name: NGC 4569 (M90)
structure: Spiral with truncated arms due to cluster interactions
formation: Affected by interactions with Virgo Cluster
funFact: One of the largest spiral galaxies in the Virgo Cluster

name: NGC 4039 (Antennae Galaxies)
structure: Colliding pair forming tidal tails
formation: Currently merging through gravitational interaction
funFact: Shows spectacular tidal tails from collision

name: NGC 891
structure: Edge-on spiral with visible dust lane
formation: Formed through gradual star formation over time
funFact: Sometimes called the ‘Outer Milky Way twin’

name: NGC 6946
structure: Face-on spiral with active star formation
formation: Formed gradually with ongoing star formation
funFact: Known as the ‘Fireworks Galaxy’ due to frequent supernovae

name: NGC 4550
structure: Two counter-rotating stellar disks
formation: Formed through galaxy merger and angular momentum conservation
funFact: Unique galaxy with counter-rotating stars

name: NGC 5866
structure: Edge-on lenticular with visible dust lane
formation: Formed via star formation cessation and aging population
funFact: Also called the ‘Spindle Galaxy’

name: NGC 4258 (M106)
structure: Spiral with anomalous arms and central activity
formation: Formed via normal spiral evolution with interactions
funFact: Famous for maser emission used to measure distance

name: NGC 3628
structure: Edge-on spiral with dust lane and tidal tail
formation: Formed through interactions with Leo Triplet members
funFact: Part of the Leo Triplet of galaxies

name: NGC 253 (Sculptor Galaxy)
structure: Starburst spiral with active star formation
formation: Formed gradually with intense starburst activity
funFact: One of the brightest spiral galaxies in the sky

name: NGC 3627 (M66)
structure: Grand-design spiral with strong arms
formation: Formed through interactions with nearby galaxies
funFact: Part of the Leo Triplet, interacting with nearby galaxies

name: NGC 1300
structure: Grand-design barred spiral galaxy
formation: Formed through gradual spiral evolution
funFact: Well-known for its well-defined bar structure

name: NGC 4414
structure: Flocculent spiral galaxy
formation: Formed through internal star formation processes
funFact: Known for loose spiral arms and star formation

name: NGC 4826 (Black Eye Galaxy)
structure: Spiral galaxy with dark dust lane across nucleus
formation: Formed through normal spiral evolution with central dust lane
funFact: Called the Black Eye Galaxy because of its prominent dust lane

name: NGC 6744
structure: Grand-design spiral resembling the Milky Way
formation: Formed via gradual spiral growth
funFact: One of the largest spiral galaxies nearby

name: NGC 4631 (Whale Galaxy)
structure: Edge-on spiral with prominent dust lane
formation: Formed through gradual disk evolution
funFact: Called the Whale Galaxy because of its shape

name: NGC 3370
structure: Face-on spiral galaxy with young star clusters
formation: Formed through star formation over time
funFact: Used to calibrate Type Ia supernova distances

name: NGC 4303 (M61)
structure: Grand-design spiral with active star-forming regions
formation: Formed via spiral density waves
funFact: One of the largest members of the Virgo Cluster

name: NGC 7331
structure: Face-on spiral with well-defined arms
formation: Formed through gradual disk formation
funFact: Sometimes called the Milky Way twin

name: NGC 6745
structure: Interacting system of three galaxies
formation: Formed via galaxy collision
funFact: Shows tidal distortions and starburst regions

name: NGC 4214
structure: Irregular dwarf galaxy with active star formation
formation: Formed through irregular gas collapse and star formation
funFact: Hosts multiple super star clusters

name: NGC 2366
structure: Irregular dwarf galaxy with active star formation
formation: Formed through irregular collapse of gas and star formation
funFact: Hosts large H II regions like NGC 2363

name: NGC 4490 (Cocoon Galaxy)
structure: Distorted spiral interacting with NGC 4485
formation: Distorted due to galaxy interaction
funFact: Also called the Cocoon Galaxy because of its shape

name: NGC 2535
structure: Interacting spiral galaxy
formation: Tidal interactions with companion galaxy
funFact: Forms a visual pair with NGC 2536

name: NGC 2903
structure: Barred spiral with star-forming regions
formation: Formed via spiral evolution and bar development
funFact: Prominent central bar with active star formation

name: NGC 3521
structure: Face-on spiral with patchy arms
formation: Formed through spiral evolution
funFact: Shows patchy spiral arms and star-forming regions

name: NGC 4565 (Needle Galaxy)
structure: Edge-on spiral with thin disk
formation: Formed via gradual spiral disk growth
funFact: Called the Needle Galaxy due to its thin edge-on profile

name: NGC 4945
structure: Edge-on spiral with active nucleus
formation: Formed through disk evolution and active nucleus formation
funFact: Hosts one of the brightest nearby active nuclei

name: NGC 1097
structure: Barred spiral with central activity
formation: Formed through spiral evolution and bar formation
funFact: Known for its central starburst and active nucleus

name: NGC 1365 (Great Barred Spiral Galaxy)
structure: Grand-design barred spiral with prominent bar
formation: Formed through spiral evolution with strong bar
funFact: One of the most famous barred spiral galaxies

name: NGC 5033
structure: Spiral galaxy with active nucleus
formation: Formed through spiral evolution with central activity
funFact: Hosts Seyfert-type active galactic nucleus
